Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Role of POU factors in the regulation of the timing of metamorphosis
Award.AbstractNarration: In many organisms, including humans, postembryonic development is marked by an abrupt change in physiology that initiates dramatic changes in growth and morphology. While the neuroendocrine changes involved in these major developmental transitions have been well characterized, the regulation underlying the timing of initiation of these changes remains poorly understood. POU factors are highly conserved transcription factors that have been shown to regulate neuroendocrine changes during puberty in vertebrates. In beetles, the removal of the POU factor, Ventral veins lacking (Vvl), also causes larvae to undergo precocious metamorphosis. The goal of the project is to examine how Vvl interacts with the known regulators of metamorphosis and to examine the roles of other POU factors during metamorphosis. To better understand what this protein does, the project will determine the regulation of the gene, the tissues in which the protein acts and its gene targets, using gene knockdown and gene expression analyses in the genetic model system, Tribolium castaneum. In both vertebrates and invertebrates, POU factors appear to play crucial roles in regulating the postembryonic developmental transitions and sexual maturity. Thus, this project has broader implications for identifying how POU factors regulate gene expression and developmental timing in a wide range of organisms. Importantly, given the current trend towards precocious puberty onset among youth, understanding the regulation of developmental transitions will have important medical and public health implications. A majority of the proposed study will involve the female undergraduate students from Wellesley College, a diverse group of people from a wide range of socioeconomic backgrounds. In addition, parts of this project will be brought into the classroom where students can conduct independent projects to learn modern molecular techniques, Finally, during the summers, the PI's lab will host a number of high school students to expose students from disadvantaged backgrounds to scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: 

The regulation of developmental timing during development remains poorly understood. In particular, while the hormones that regulate metamorphosis entry in insects and puberty entry in humans are well understood, we do not know how these hormones are set in motion, what the upstream regulators are, and how the body senses its size. This project sought to investigate the mechanism underlying regulation of developmental timing in insects with a particular focus on the POU transcription factor, Ventral veins lacking (Vvl). This protein shares high sequence homology with vertebrate POU factors. We found that this protein regulates the expression of major developmental hormones, juvenile hormone (JH) and ecdysteroids, which are involved in both maturation and oogenesis. We found that insects, Vvl plays a critical role in regulating the production of these hormones to affect both metamorphic timing and oogenesis. Our finding suggests a possible deep homology of POU factors in regulating sexual maturation across metazoans, including both humans and insects. In addition, we have uncovered a critical role for JH in regulating the critical weight and minimum viable weight in tobacco hornworms and have demonstrated that JH and TOR signaling pathway act in opposing manner to regulate the timing of metamorphosis. In particular, we identified JH as critical mediator of life history trade-off between large body size and faster developmental maturation. Finally, the study has uncovered a novel role for a nutrient sensitive process in regulating the size threshold necessary for initiating metamorphosis: lower nutrient condition shifts the threshold to a higher body size. Our study has potential broader implications for understanding the rise in precocious puberty associated with an increase in obesity prevalence. 

 

Broader impacts:

Funding for this project has provided research training in my research lab for 29 female undergraduate students, including several minority students. A number of these students have presented their work at the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology meetings and have also co-authored manuscripts in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, the funding has allowed us to host six female high school students from Framingham High School through the Framingham-Wellesley Summer Outreach program. This program enables underrepresented students to gain exposure to scientific research while also providing Wellesley students with valuable mentoring experience. The funding has also allowed us to invite two additional high school students to work in the lab over the summer. Finally, the funding has enabled students to do a semester long independent research project in the classroom where students gained experience in research design and molecular biology. This opportunity has provided independent research experiences to over 50 undergraduate students.
